subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: This is good. It indicates strength in the original design. If we maintain the linkage you proposed earlier, we now have: SQUARE    Eight + Roe NEAR      Eat +
messageBody:
This is good. It indicates strength in the original design. If we
maintain the linkage you proposed earlier, we now have:

SQUARE Eight + Roe
NEAR Eat + Roe
CURE Ooze + Roe

Has anyone yet looked in the QM for examples of NEAR and CURE words?

Ted


On Nov 14, 2007 8:50 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> myzomela63 scripsit:
>
>
> > One suggestion: for NEAR, I'd keep #26It-#25Roe as the first
> > transcription, but #27EAt-#25Roe as an alternative - as you've done
> > on the American chart. I hear both on the street - and on TV shows
> > where Australian accents are exaggerated for comic effect.
>
> I actually thought of a good reason for using Ate-Roe instead of Et-Roe
> for the SQUARE set.
>
> Consider the words "ferry" and "fairy". All non-rhotics and some rhotics
> pronounce them differently, whereas many rhotics make them the same.
> What are the lexical sets?
>
> Non-rhotics make "ferry" DRESS and "fairy" FACE, with the /r/ in the
> next syllable in both cases (which is why it's pronounced; non-rhotics
> don't drop /r/ at the beginning of a syllable.) For rhotics who do
> distinguish between the two, "ferry" is likewise DRESS with the /r/
> belonging to the second syllable, whereas "fairy" is definitely SQUARE.
> For rhotics who merge, both "fairy" and "ferry" are SQUARE.
>
> So if we use Et-Roe for SQUARE, what are we to use for DRESS when /r/
> follows? If we use Ate-Roe, though, "fairy" is Fee-Eat-Roe-It, whereas
> "ferry" is Fee-Et-Roe-It.
>
>
> > And one warning. Some Australians may want to keep terminal
> > unstressed "Eat" written as #27Eat, rather than #26It.
>
> Just about the only reason to keep HAPPY (final unstressed /i/) as It
> rather than Eat is that Read prescribes it (it was standard RP in his
> day, though it no longer is). Otherwise only a few varieties use it;
> I'd be happy to have everyone else use Eat.
>
> --
> While staying with the Asonu, I met a man from John Cowan
> the Candensian plane, which is very much like cowan@...
> ours, only more of it consists of Toronto. http://:www.ccil.org/~cowan
> --Ursula K. Le Guin, Changing Planes
>
>
